tasks.title: Analyze pipeline dependencies and identify parallelism opportunities
subtasks: Read CLAUDE.md pipeline documentation, project-kickoff skill, and acceptance-criteria skill
Analyzed 4 completed project task files (roadmap-tool, work-item-tracker, dashboard-navigation, early-qa-notification) for actual dependency patterns
Mapped all 12 true sequential dependencies with evidence for why each is a hard gate
Identified 4 parallelism opportunities with risk assessment for each
Analyzed Jonah's work across projects -- confirmed zero dependencies on Robert's design spec in every case
Mapped current critical path (10 serial steps) vs proposed critical path (8 serial steps)
Wrote impact assessment with time-saved and risk ratings for each optimization
Documented what NOT to change -- preserved hard dependencies that prevent rework
Included evidence appendix citing specific agent outputs from 4 shipped projects
Created proposed pipeline diagram showing parallel tracks
decisions: Jonah parallel with Robert is the highest-impact change -- removes an entire phase from backend start time with low risk because API contracts are defined in the tech approach, not the design spec
Priya can start after Thomas's requirements -- messaging is based on product scope, not implementation details. Medium risk of revision if scope changes during build, but scope rarely changes
Nadia can overlap with Enzo -- docs are based on what was built, not whether QA passed. QA fixes rarely change documented behavior
Yuki data collection during QA is low-impact but removes artificial serialization
Alice CANNOT start earlier -- she genuinely needs both the design spec (from Robert) and API contracts (from Andrei/tech approach). This is a true hard dependency
This is a process change only -- requires updates to CLAUDE.md, project-kickoff skill, and Thomas's agent definition. No code changes.
No downstream agents needed -- this is an analysis project, not a build project
